name: Future of Economic Progress

dimensions.subtitle: Progressive taxation can address inequality, though fiscal spending priorities vary widely among countries
dimensions.description: In its World Economic Outlook published in late 2018, the International Monetary Fund noted that the US’s recent tax overhaul is likely to widen the country’s fiscal deficit - which had already been under pressure, due to spending on support for the country’s ageing population. dimensions.name: Economics of Environmental Sustainability
dimensions.subtitle: Climate change and rising temperatures promise to severely hinder production and health
dimensions.description: In late 2018, the UN’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change issued an alarming report noting that global temperatures are on track to be 1.5°C higher than the preindustrial era as soon as 2030. Currently, at 1°C warmer than the preindustrial era, we are already experiencing severe consequences of climate change including forest fires in the Arctic, and the increased intensity of hurricanes. dimensions.name: Economics of the Fourth Industrial Revolution
dimensions.subtitle: Technologies are quickly developing and merging, testing traditional means of economic growth
dimensions.description: Responses to technological change can determine the shape of economic progress. Technology that can serve to automate tasks now performed by significant portions of a country’s existing workforce, for example, can potentially do at least as much damage to the social fabric as the good it can do for productivity metrics. dimensions.name: Inclusive Growth
dimensions.subtitle: A failure to improve living standards and reduce inequality has worsened social divides
dimensions.description: Even as global labour productivity grew by 74% between 1973 and 2013, worker compensation grew by just 12.5% over the same period, according to the Economic Policy Institute. While a relatively recent slowdown in global productivity has contributed to the reduction of the real value of salaries, other forces are also at work - such as rapid technological change, evolving market structures, and globalization, all of which began impacting distribution patterns even before the productivity slowdown...

dimensions.name: Productivity and Competitiveness
dimensions.subtitle: Productivity is difficult to measure, but essential for increasing prosperity
dimensions.description: In 2017, International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned that living standards around the world could be lowered if the rate of global productivity did not pick up.
